Last night in class, we explored the assigned reading, "Toward a Renewed Study of the Place-World" by Edward S. Casey. The first chapter, "Implacement," and the second, "Displacement," introduced key concepts. Casey argues that our contemporary world and culture revolve around time as the situating force. He contends that we're running out of time, have saved time, and are just in time. The author is making the case that using place as the center of culture fosters a more grounded community. This book has captivated me, providing a unique perspective that resonates deeply.

Magic fans beware... Wizards are hesitant to create a decent digital game. At its core, the gathering is a social game. A game to enjoy with friends (or frenemies) laughing, talking smack, and dropping game-winning bombs. The coast's wizards seem to have forgotten this. If you choose to play with friends, you can earn gold, and gold is crucial. Gold is so vital that they have implemented a daily cap, understandable considering gold unlocks everything in the game. But get ready for a long and arduous 1v1 grind against the computer or random opponents, whom you can't even communicate with. If you choose to play for free, it will take you roughly 4 hours a day for upwards of a month, by yourself, to unlock the cards.

I'll get the bad stuff out of the way first. As the third installment in the trilogy, I'll address my issues with pre-quals. I strongly dislike them, as they technically move the story backward, not forward. While it provides more story, the combat feels sloppy and doesn't feel as sharp as Arkham City managed to achieve. As of the writing of this recommendation (26/10/2013), there is a game-breaking bug that prevents a side mission from ever being completed (the main story is not affected). Some gadgets are placed at an unreasonable hotkey location, requiring your hand to travel the entire keyboard to access them. Although it may seem insignificant, it could potentially break your combo while in combat.

The game, Shadow Warrior 2013, has several notable features. The boss battles are truly impressive, with weapons that feel very satisfying to use. Enemies are not overly abundant, requiring players to handle elemental and upgrade systems with care. The upgrade system is well-balanced, making it easy to progress without becoming tedious. The elemental abilities and limited ammo encourage players to use a variety of weapons. The game features a range of unique and viable weapons that remain effective throughout most of the game. The soundtrack is excellent, with the main theme and additional tracks by Stan Bush being particularly noteworthy.

So, many things went wrong. I'm having trouble starting this review, as it's all related to my career. My player is an outside scorer, 1.71m, with maxed stats and all necessary perks. Now, I'd like to know why the shooting skill depends on a person's height. Why can't a person with 1.74m become as good at shooting as someone with 1.71m? I'm 1.87m in RL, and I created my first player with this height. I noticed then I can't reach a higher skill than 89. Why is that a pure discrimination? And why doesn't the game inform me of this before I create a character, and not even then when I reach the skill limit after weeks of playing?!

I think the assassin's creed nailed the mechanics down on all fronts, including ship battles, sailing, hunting, parkour, and other aspects. I felt more attached to this character as well. The story starts out rough but improves significantly as you progress. Edward was an interesting character, as were all the side characters. I felt like all the collectibles actually served a purpose in this game, something I never got from any of the previous ones, perhaps because I felt they had a greater significance in the game. They were not essential, but they were enjoyable to acquire and you were rewarded in a well-balanced manner.

While I personally cannot recommend this game, it wasn't absolutely terrible. The gunplay is alright, so long as you have the money to purchase gun parts, which would be my main complaint. If I could get past that, the game would be enjoyable, as the hardsuit is fun to use and hrv is an excellent idea.

While not perfect, this game has been greatly enjoyable. The save system and possibility of sudden death lead to some frustration. I'm on my first playthrough and I lost my main character around hour 10 of 20ish. I would have liked a save to reload at that point. I've since picked up a 3rd party mod/save tool to avoid catastrophic failures. The aiming reticule is on the small side and zoom is underpowered. Despite these issues, it's been a blast. I'm not normally a zombie fan, but the combination of strategy, missions, first-person shooter/beat-em-up is great.

An absolute great strategy game! Having played every single other war game (European Escalation and Albion), I have to say this one fits well. The number of units is great. Not sure exactly how many units there are, but there's a crap ton! Graphics are just beautiful, sounds are great, and the gameplay overall is epic. The in-game chat box at the main menu is very entertaining, as well. However, if anyone thinking this game is 'easy', or if you're new to the strategy genre, it could take you quite some time to get it nailed down. Don't get upset, you'll lose a lot of units. Just make sure you plan ahead, always have anti-air, and anti-tank.

I was initially skeptical about this game before I played it. The portal gun and portal thing seemed unusual to me, even though I enjoy science fiction. But boy, I was wrong. The humor and voice acting in this game are phenomenal. The story characters have their own sense of humor, and the level design is simply amazing.

Yes, this is a nostalgia trip for thirty-somethings who remember watching the ever-irritating Transformers cartoon. The voice actors for Optimus, Megatron, Bumblebee, and many others are back, instantly recognizable. The distinctive cartoon transformation sound is present. Graphically, the cell-shaded presentation is perfect, and very, very Generation One. The combat mechanics are extremely well done. Transforming mid-fight is often a necessity, seamlessly woven into combos, making it quite unlike High Moon's excellent War for/Energon games.

I downloaded the game and played it for a bit, but it didn't impress me. I spent more time trying to log in than playing the game. The game has a glitch where it prompts you to update the terms of service, but clicking "accept" doesn't work. You need to restart the client for it to function. While it's not a major issue, I'm concerned about linking my Steam and Gface accounts. They claim it's for DLC, but I don't see why that's necessary. Moreover, it's not reversible, so now I know a company I don't care about has access to my Steam information. The game itself is unoriginal, easily recognizable as a Call of Duty clone, except they somehow managed to make the gunplay worse.

4K at 60fps with a GTX 970, dual audio options, and Neptune gear â€“ what's not to love? (https //www.youtube.com/watch?v=nygsb617tmo) This excellent port serves as a great entry point for newcomers to the series. However, be aware that there is considerable dialogue, which can be skipped. I recommend using a gamepad, but the keyboard and mouse setup worked seamlessly, with both controls fully customizable. The price is reasonable, and I wouldn't have been disappointed with a purchase. Over half the DLC is included at no extra cost, providing ample gameplay. I highly recommend this game to JRPG, anime, and visual novel fans, provided you can tolerate occasional breaks between action sequences.

I experienced no performance issues at release, and after numerous patches, the game plays exceptionally well. In my opinion, this is a truly great and enjoyable game, with a few minor drawbacks. The format may be somewhat inconvenient, particularly in the free-roam city area, where the environment repopulates with new enemies upon progressing the story. I particularly enjoyed the 'dual play' segments, where you can play as Batman and another character, and the option to use the controller for most parts of the game, while using the mouse and keyboard for the tank combat sections was greatly appreciated. Driving the Batmobile around the city, including when chasing the APC commanders, is actually quite enjoyable once you master the braking technique to navigate around corners.

The bottom line is a damn fine fps shooter. It looks, sounds, and plays great, with great fps mechanics, a nice story, cool characters, flawless voice acting, and a badass soundtrack. Not for the faint of heart, though - some cutscenes were pretty darn cruel and vivid. However, when a game is this great, it's easier to spot the flaws, and here they are as I saw them  no SLI support - what a weird issue. I had to put the game away until I upgraded my card, as it ran too poorly on my old dual GPU GTX 590. Make sure you have a fairly decent single GPU card. Stupidly small obstacles are often unclimbable.

The game's graphics have been set in a comic-like style, with very slick visuals and nice color schemes. The graphics can be set to "high" without straining your system. I run the game on an i5 Pentium processor, with an Nvidia GeForce 710M card and 8GB of memory, and it runs smoothly on Windows 8.1. The controls are also flexible, allowing for play with a keyboard and mouse or an Xbox controller.

You can see the hours I've put into this game, and I enjoy it immensely. This is everything I wished a search game from CD Projekt would be. But don't buy this game thinking it's like CD Projekt, Battlefield, or any other shooter game. It's a game in its own class and should be treated as such. I can't tell you how many times I've heard new players complain about getting killed really fast. Oh, god forbid you get shot in the face and die. It's not like that doesn't happen in real life or anything. I've been playing this game for a while now, throwing all kinds of money at it. One of the best multiplayer games around. A good thing to play when you're not feeling CS GO.

I'm two hours in and I'm dying from laughter from this game. The gameplay is solid, the art design is beautiful, the music is surprisingly high-quality and fitting, and the story/world has me hooked. The puzzles are fun, but the best part is the comedy. If you've played any RPG since the dawn of video game RPGs, you'll laugh at the various jokes, parodies, and references. If you're new to RPGs, you'll still enjoy the game for its humor. If you played Final Fantasy 7 or X, you absolutely need to play this game. I had to stop playing after two hours to give my cheeks a break from laughing and smiling so much. What a delight so far.

I'm truly sorry to say, but I tried to be supportive of free-to-play games and indie developers, but I simply didn't enjoy this game. The description sounded right up my alley, but the execution fell short for me. I love puzzle and exploration games, but I found this game to be completely unintuitive, and even after looking up how to progress, I still just simply didn't find the gameplay itself engaging. It also lacks a pause button, which is a critical oversight, especially considering that many sequences in the game are timed. I feel like this game is a lot more cutscene than it is game, and I often find myself simply sitting around waiting for something to happen.

This game was an incredible experience from start to finish. It was absolutely beautiful, with a story that drew me in and graphics that kept me engaged. The story wasn't just a narrative, but it felt like I was the character, trying to unravel the mystery of what was to come next. The gameplay was excellent, and I learned a lot about myself through this game, particularly about my fear of heights, which I never had a problem with until the ice caverns. My gut was churning the whole time, but I persisted for Uncle Fred! If you guys created a DLC or second game, I would be the first to buy it and recommend it to everyone I know. Thank you to everyone involved in making this, you created an absolutely beautiful game.

Sid Meier's Civilization  Beyond Earth is a turn-based game where you build your civilization to a specific goal or 'victory'. In this game, you're set in the future on a mission to colonize a new planet. I enjoy the 2K approach, which added new mechanics like the affinity system and orbital layer. However, the game can be overwhelming at times. To improve this, incorporating new artwork, such as the environment when communicating with another leader, could be beneficial.

Great game! It offers tons of replayability and is very fun, a zombie survival game! In my top 5 zombie games ever played. After playing 60+ hours, I can honestly say this is one of the better, more realistic zombie games. It's very much designed like a survival horror, as you must save up your ammo, heal your own wounds when you bleed out, take pills when you're infected, etc. I find zombies to feel very natural to be well animated, for a free-to-play game. I would recommend getting one or two friends to play with, but the community is super friendly, and you can usually make friends/talk with the people in the chat or over voice comms.

It's a shame I can't thoroughly recommend or enjoy this game, as from the short time I've played it, I know I'd be addicted if it didn't have the following two game-breakers. No Aussie servers - one red bar puts you at a severe disadvantage, and creates unbearable lag. I played through the offline training mode and it was stuttering and lagging as well (how does that even happen?). Couple that with the poor ping, and it just ruins the game. Everything is artifacts like crazy - the menus, backgrounds, training, and in-game. I've never had this happen before with this card, and thought it might not like my OC.

I recently completed this game, and while it may not be particularly deep or engrossing, the storytelling is what truly stands out. The atmosphere is richly detailed, and the many collectibles do an excellent job of fleshing it out. I learned a lot about the world of Batman, which was a pleasant surprise. Although it was a bit disappointing that there were so few boss battles, there are certainly enough future games to rectify that. The combat is moderately challenging, but it's more on the easy side. Leveling up Batman wasn't particularly satisfying, but the gadgets you acquire and upgrade during the campaign add a nice layer of depth to the gameplay. The ability to access previously unreachable areas is a nice touch, providing a sense of progression.

To the moon is no mere game; nay, it is a veritable experience, and it was one of the best of my life at that. Telltale's The Walking Dead is sad? Hohoho! Well, it's no match for to the moon! Never before have I been so depressed yet fulfilled over something purely fictional. This masterpiece represents the pinnacle of storytelling in my opinion, and the soundtrack is a gorgeously charming and perfect accompaniment. Yes, the controls are a bit finicky, and the gameplay is not the strong point, but the story is so fantastic that I did not care one bit. Plus, the humor is great, and it definitely does not intrude upon the distinguished nature of the story.

Bastion is a brilliant game with a great storyline. After a calamity, you start rebuilding on the bastion, with many choices to give you an advantage. You choose what to build, what weapons to use, what power-ups for those weapons, and what drinks for a bonus effect. The art style and music are fantastic, making the game visually stunning. The narration is based on your actions, so if you pick up a weapon, the narrator will comment on your choice.

I originally acquired this game in its early development phase, when the primary currency was spacebux and the tech tree was non-existent. At this stage, the game was enjoyable. All the weapons were equally overpowered, eliminating the issue of balance; any player could kill anyone at any time. Additionally, the game provided unlimited gun slots and five loadouts. One might expect that for a game with 'billions of guns', they would at least provide more than six weapon slots and three loadouts before requiring additional purchases. I once had approximately three pages worth of weapons, and was planning new ideas for more, as I found it enjoyable.

This game was a delightful surprise. One often sees glowing reviews of certain products that can be misleading. In this case, the reviews reflect the fun of this charming little game. It's an intriguing blend of a classic 2D platformer and a MOBA, and it pulls it off with style. I found myself enjoying characters that I wouldn't typically enjoy in other MOBA games. I had expected this trait to continue, but decided to give a melee tank a try anyway. I was pleasantly surprised with the outcome and ended up trying out more as they were unlocked from playing games. The art style and interface is charmingly unique. As such, I now use one of the characters as my avatar and a wallpaper from creating a card set for the game.

I recently discovered a game that has captivated me, and I find myself engrossed in it for hours on end. The immersive experience is unparalleled, with the music setting the tone, sound effects precisely calibrated, and controls finely tuned. I eagerly anticipate each combat encounter, which is expertly executed. Initially, I had reservations about the naval combat system, but I now find it thrilling to unleash havoc on multiple fleets at once. The only way to lose is to fail to retreat. If the combat appears overwhelming, simply retreat, regroup, and counter-attack. Thank you to the developers for crafting an exceptional experience.

The reboot of the Devil May Cry franchise has brought about many changes for the series, particularly for its protagonist, Dante. While fans of the original series may be upset at the change to their beloved character, it's certainly for the better; and this new game by Ninja Theory proves it. The game serves as the perfect point for newcomers to jump into the series. It shows the origins of an arrogant, cynical Dante, and it chronicles his journey from cynicism to selflessness.

Where do I start on this absolutely beautiful game? It's story is absolutely charming, with so much detail put into it, and it is a bundle of happiness, bad puns, and annoying dogs, secrets. The character design is on point, with various characters having various personalities and secrets to them. It stands out from other RPGs because you don't have to kill anyone, which is an unused concept in RPGs.

I'm recommending this solely because it's free, and it might be a more enjoyable experience for others. As for my experience, the game did nothing for me. Half the story relies on shock factor. I wasn't shocked nor emotionally moved in any way by this. Maybe I'm desensitized, or maybe it was too simple to warrant a reaction out of me. The other half of the game tries to paint a picture of a person in mental decline. It deals with obsession, hallucinations, depression, and a few other things.

Do I even need to explain why Portal is amazing? Portal is a puzzle game that presents a concept, then takes it away. It's an engaging way to test your mind while still being enjoyable. Although this game isn't as story-driven, it gave birth to one of the most popular games of 2011. I still play this game when I'm feeling bored and I love to come back and see what gave birth to a legend and what is a legend. The gameplay is quite simple  use portals to your advantage, along with buttons that activate a part of the puzzle.

If you can overlook the bugs, which I personally only had two  one minor and the other quite annoying, I can definitely recommend this space exploration game. I'll include my specs for reference  i5 6600k, Radeon RX480, Z170 Pro - Gaming, 16GB DDR4 RAM, and a price tag of ~650â‚¬. This setup is definitely within the medium price range.

Remember the age of mythology? Yeah, it's been that long since there's been an RTS game of such quality. Divinity  Dragon Commander reaches awfully close to these borders of my personal most favourite RTS game. Combine this with a huge risk-like grand strategy mode and there, it hits the spot. I am not overly biased due to the fact that this game allows you to turn into a dragon, aiding your troops by supporting, attacking, and even commanding unit production, direction, and spawning at the very same time. Honestly, I do like the complicated RTS games nowadays. Think of Civ V and so on. However, such games attempt to cram complex mechanics, charts, and resources all into one complicated game mode.

I've had this game for a relatively short period, but in that brief time, two DLCs have been released, along with patches that have transformed an already impressive game into an outstanding one. The developers are highly active in the community, which is evident in the various discussion forums and developer diaries. While there is a considerable learning curve to the game's mechanics, this breadth of strategy allows for a multitude of ways to achieve goals and capitalize on certain situations. In my opinion, the game is almost infinitely replayable. I find myself fully immersed in every session I play, regardless of how the play-through unfolds.

Warframe is a fun game for the first few hours of play. After those few enjoyable hours, you'll begin to see that the game's content is repetitive in its combat, enemies, and gameplay. The one major high point is that the developers are working hard and do semi-frequent updates, which generally include a lot of content, such as sweeping changes, new Warframes, and other tweaks and features. It's a good game to play casually.

This game is somewhat disappointing. I purchased this game because I thought it was a PC version of "Katamari Damacy," a popular and enjoyable PS2 game. Unfortunately, it's far from it. In this game, you progress by absorbing increasingly larger objects to grow bigger and absorb even bigger things. However, the gameplay isn't as smooth as it could be, and the levels lack inventiveness, with a surreal horror show that leaves me feeling rather depressed and questioning whether being alive is all it should be. Every living creature in this game, from small pets to human beings, makes me wonder if the creators of this game had an interest in taxidermy.

I'm a keen observer of politics, and when I first learned about this game, I was intrigued. I thought, "Ah, a simulator of the road to becoming president! That sounds engaging!" However, it didn't quite live up to my expectations. The game begins by asking you to choose a side  Republican or Democrat, with no independent or third-party options available. I was a bit disappointed, but still optimistic, I decided to continue playing to see what I could do. I'll give the game credit where it's due, the character customization, although limited, is enjoyable to experiment with. It's the only time it's an option to wear your head or not in a campaign, literally.

The Fallout 3 story is marred by the presence of settlements, which can hinder the experience to the point where you'll find yourself baby-sitting them instead of playing the story. Some keys are hard-coded and cannot be rebound. Bugs abound. My Pip-Boy disappeared permanently at one point and I had to research console commands to get it back. You don't have to work for power armor; it's essentially given to you from the beginning of the game, and power cores are abundant in trader shops. The value of power armor is diminished greatly from previous Fallout games. The story is mediocre, with everything about this game being average except for its stability, which is significantly better than Fallout 3. It doesn't crash every 10 minutes like Fallout 3, making it a more stable experience. Is it better than Fallout 3? No. Is it better than New Vegas? No. The title was overhyped for how bad it actually is.

My stats (at the time of writing this review)  - 8.6 hours to get to the end - 10 collectibles found out of 25 - zero achievements out of 15. What I liked  - visuals up until the last level (ice caves) - story is not that great, but the ending (after the closing credits) kind of made me not regret so much spending my time playing this game. What I disliked  - visuals in the last level are uninteresting - gameplay in the last level gets much harder, making it become a frustrating experience of having to do a lot of things over and over again until you get it right.

Pros  +graphic cons  -bugs, especially environmental bugs that may cause you to get stuck or your shots to hit an invisible wall despite having a clear line of sight of the enemy. -game is handholding/babysitting you -dumb AI -enemies always seem to know where you are when you are spotted -godlike accuracy by the enemy, which is frustrating like the first Ghost Warrior. -terrible checkpoints and saves. -boring story that I couldn't care less about, I won't recommend it unless it's 90% off, even then I find playing this game to be an extremely boring chore, just playing for the sake of finishing it to move unto the next game in my library.

It's not difficult for me to see why others enjoy this game, but it wasn't for me. For one thing, I have a preference for playing room-sized games with controllers. Beyond that, the game's awe-inspiring scale is initially impressive, but I felt that same scale hindered my enjoyment. The learning curve and the time it takes to do anything interesting at the start were too great for me.

My favorite first-person shooter of all time is hands down. Run-and-gun rambos are not necessary. Recoil and ballistics are realistic. Single hits to the chest, neck, or head from rifle-caliber weapons almost always result in death unless they just graze you. Rounds drop over distance and short, controlled bursts are required to remain on target. There is no magical ammunition pool. If you reload half-way through your magazine, you'll have a pouch full of half-full mags. You can't run forever. If you sprint for a while, your aim will suffer as you gasp heavily until you've caught your breath. Rest your weapon on your elbows while prone or on a window sill to steady your aim. Accuracy suffers when standing.

Let me start by saying I didn't purchase Eu when it first came out, and I got it on sale, which included Ew, so I never experienced the issues some people claim to have had with that game. I loved the game, however, it was unforgiving in the early stages, but rewarding when you did things right. As for XCOM2, I love it; the game plays well on medium for me, running a GTX560 with 2GB of VRAM. Initially, the game set it to high, and it was running a bit sluggishly, but not to the point of being unplayable. When I dropped it down to medium, it smoothed out.

This game offers a wide variety of ship types, featuring physics-based movement for both ships and projectiles/missiles. The resource management is easy to learn and understand. While it may not be perfect, the game has some enjoyable moments. The game starts off quickly and maintains a good pace. Although there's a limited selection of equipment and leveling skills, it still feels like there's always something new to unlock or level up. The best way to enhance the game is through mods, which add new content and variety to the game. The main focus is on the fight for survival, but the big battles for resources are also very engaging.

World leaders gather to face uncertainty, more than 2,000 business and political leaders from around the globe are arriving in the Swiss mountain resort of Davos for the annual World Economic Forum (WEF). For five days, they will discuss issues ranging from China's economic power to Iraq's future after this Sunday's elections. UK Prime Minister Tony Blair and South African President Thabo Mbeki are among the more than 20 government leaders and heads of state leaders attending the meeting. Unlike previous years, protests against the WEf are expected to be muted. Anti-globalisation campaigners have called off a demonstration planned for the weekend. The Brazilian city of Porto Alegre will host the rival World Social Forum, timed to run in parallel with the WEf's more exclusive event in Davos.

Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor has criticized the Iraq War, stating that the billions of pounds spent on the conflict in Iraq and the Middle East should have been used to reduce poverty. In a Christmas message, he denounced the war as a "terrible" waste of money. Speaking on BBC Radio 4's Thought for the Day slot, he expressed his concern that billions have been spent on war, rather than addressing dire poverty, malnutrition, and disease.

Debra Hill, the renowned screenwriter and producer behind the 1978 horror classic Halloween, has passed away at the age of 54 in Los Angeles. Hill, who had been battling cancer, co-wrote the film that catapulted Jamie Lee Curtis to stardom as a babysitter terrorized by a psychopath. Directed by John Carpenter, the film grossed over $60 million worldwide, a record for an independent film at the time. Hill also collaborated with Carpenter on Escape from New York and The Fog. Born in New Jersey, Hill began her career as a production assistant and worked her way up the ranks, becoming an assistant director and second-unit director before teaming up with Carpenter. She was a trailblazing woman in the film industry, taking on roles in the 1970s that were typically dominated by men.

Broadband fuels online expression, enabling fast web access, is encouraging more people to express themselves online, research suggests. According to a report by UK think-tank Demos, a quarter of broadband users in Britain regularly upload content to their personal sites. The report highlights that having an always-on, fast connection is transforming the way people use the internet. More than five million households in the UK now have broadband, and this number is growing rapidly. The Demos report examined the impact of broadband on people's online habits. It found that more than half of those with broadband log on to the web before breakfast. One in five even admitted to getting up in the middle of the night to browse the web. Significantly, the report argues that broadband is encouraging people to take a more active role online.

Yukos, the Russian oil and gas company, is facing a US court hearing on Thursday as it continues to fight for its survival. The firm is being broken up by Russian authorities to pay a $27 billion tax bill. Yukos filed for bankruptcy in the US, hoping to use international business law to halt the forced sale of its key oil production unit, Yugasnkneftegas. The unit was sold for $9.4 billion to state oil firm Rosneft, but only after the state auction was disrupted. Yukos lawyers now say the auction violated US bankruptcy law. The company and its main shareholders have vowed to pursue any company that buys its assets, using all legal means.

Voters flock to the blog awards site, where the annual Bloggies recognize the best web blogs, online spaces where people publish their thoughts of the year. Nominations were announced on Sunday, but traffic to the official site was so heavy that it was temporarily closed due to an overwhelming number of visitors. Weblogs have been nominated in 30 categories, ranging from the top regional blog to the best-kept-secret blog. Blogs have had a remarkable year, with the term "blog" being named the word of 2004 by a top US dictionary. According to Technorati, a blog search engine, over six million blogs are tracked, with more than 12,000 new ones added daily. Research from Pew Internet and American Life suggests that a blog is created every 5.8 seconds, but less than 40% of these are updated at least once every two months.

The Chinese dam firm, Beijing Three Gorges Project Corp, is defying a government order to stop construction of one of its giant dams, according to the Chinese state press. Despite the order, the company is continuing work on the Xiluodu Dam, the Beijing News reported. The Xiluodu Dam is one of 30 large-scale construction projects halted due to a lack of proper environmental checks. The Beijing News said the company may instead choose to pay a fine.

Manchester United reduced Chelsea's Premier League lead to nine points after a scrappy victory over Manchester City. Wayne Rooney met Gary Neville's cross to the near post with a low shot, which went in via a deflection off Richard Dunne, to put United ahead. Seven minutes later, the unfortunate Dunne hooked a volley over David James' head and into his own net. Steve McManaman wasted City's best chance when he shot wide from three yards in the first half. In the opening 45 minutes, United had looked unlikely to earn the win they needed to maintain any chance of catching Chelsea in the title race. Their approach play was more laboured than patient and they managed to fashion just one chance - a Paul Scholes header over the bar.

Singer George Michael's documentary film will be showcased at this year's Berlin Film Festival. The documentary takes a candid look at the life of the chart-topping singer, exploring his career and personal life, from his early days in Wham! to more recent events. The 93-minute film will feature Michael discussing his early days, as well as his later career, including his legal battles with Sony and his stance against the Iraq War and American politics. The film will be screened in the Panorama section of the festival, which runs from February 10-20. Michael will attend the festival to introduce the screening on February 16. Director Southan Morris and Executive Producer Andy Stephens will also be in attendance.

For the first time, digital music downloads are being included in the main US singles chart. Billboard's hot 100 chart now incorporates data from sales of music downloads, previously only assigned to a separate download chart. Green Day's Boulevard of Broken Dreams is currently number two in Billboard's pop chart, and tops its digital chart. Download sales are set to be incorporated into the UK singles chart later this year. Digital sales in the US are already used to compile Billboard's hot digital sales chart. They will now be tallied with sales of physical singles and airplay information to make up its new hot 100 chart.

The self-proclaimed spam king, Scott Richter, and his company, Optinrealbig.com, are seeking bankruptcy protection after being forced into Chapter 11 due to lawsuits. Richter, who was listed as the third biggest spammer in the world by Junk Mail Watchdog Spamhaus, has been sued in December 2003 for sending millions of spam messages that violated anti-spam laws. The company is fighting several legal battles, including one against Microsoft, which is seeking millions of dollars in damages. Filing for Chapter 11 would help the company resolve its legal issues while still allowing it to continue trading.

Arnesen denies rift with Santini, Tottenham's sporting director, Frank Arnesen, has denied that coach Jacques Santini resigned because of a clash of personalities at White Hart Lane. There had been newspaper speculation that Santini had felt undermined by Arnesen's role at the club. "It is absolutely not true," Arnesen told BBC Radio 5 Live. "There is only one thing that made him resign, and that is his own personal problems." Arnesen said he was unable to throw any light onto the problems that caused Santini to quit after just 13 games in charge. He added, "Jacques has never gone into exactly what it was. But I trust him in that; you have to accept it. I think we should respect it."

Economy will be at the heart of the election campaign, Chancellor Gordon Brown said after the cabinet meeting at 10 Downing Street. He emphasized that voters will recognize that Labour has brought stability and growth, and will continue to do so. Meanwhile, the Tories outlined their plans to tackle "yob culture" and the Lib Dems gave more details about their proposals to replace council tax.

Brizzel to run in Sheffield's AAA Championships, eight Irish hopefuls will compete. Paul Brizzel, the 200m title defender, will be among them. Alistair Cragg and Mark Carroll, the only Irish athletes selected so far, will not participate in Sheffield. Brizzel will defend his title in the British trials. In-form James McIlroy will hope to confirm his place in the British team for Madrid by winning the 800m title. McIlroy has been in tremendous form on the European circuit in recent weeks, and he seems assured of a place in Madrid.

Robinson, a former rugby league international, has targeted dual code success over Australia on Saturday. The former rugby league captain, Jason Robinson, leads England against Australia at Twickenham at 14 30 GMT. England have the chance to seal their third autumn international victory after successive wins over Canada and South Africa, as well as gaining revenge for June's 51-15 hammering by the Wallabies.

Warning  A tsunami aid website is claiming to collect cash on behalf of tsunami victims. The site appears plausible due to its use of an old version of the official disasters emergency committee webpage. However, it has no connection with the fake site and has contacted the police about it. The site is just the latest in a long list of scams that try to cash in on the goodwill generated by the tsunami disaster. Be cautious when clicking on links contained in spam emails, especially those with poor grammar and spelling.

Iraq is inviting bids for two telephone licences to significantly boost nationwide coverage over the next decade. Bids have been invited from local, Arab and foreign companies. The winner will work in partnership with the Iraqi telecommunications and post company, ITPC. The firms will install and operate a fixed phone network, providing voice, fax and internet services. The ministry aims to increase Iraq's "very low telephone service penetration rate from about 4.5% to about 25% within 10 years, developing a highly visible and changeable telecommunications sector.

More women are turning to net security, taking charge of protecting home computers against malicious net attacks, according to a two-year study. The number of women buying programs to protect PCs from virus, spam and spyware attacks rose by 11.2% each year between 2002 and 2004. The study, for net security firm preventon, shows that security messages are reaching a diverse range of surfers. It is thought that 40% of those buying home net security programs are retired.

Podcasts mark the rise of DIY radio, an apple iPod or other digital music players, can hold anything up to 10,000 songs, which is a significant amount of space to fill. However, more and more iPod owners are filling that space with audio content created by an unpredictable assortment of producers. The term "podcasting" takes its name from the apple iPod, although you don't need an iPod to create one or to listen to a podcast. A podcast is essentially an internet-based radio show, which podcasters create, usually in the comfort of their own home. They require only a microphone, a PC, and some editing software. They then upload their shows to the internet and others can download and listen to them, all for free.

Levy wins the Whitbread Novel Prize, and Andrea Levy has seen her book, Small Island, win the Whitbread Novel of the Year award. She is now the favourite to win the overall prize after beating Booker Prize winner Alan Hollinghurst's The Line of Beauty. Geraldine McCaughrean has picked up the children's fiction award for the third time for Not the End of the World. All the category winners go through to compete for the Whitbread Book of the Year title, which carries a Â£25,000 prize.

Yukos seeks court action in the US on Wednesday to seek sanctions against Baikal Finance Group, the little-known firm that has bought its main asset. Yukos has said it will sue Baikal and others involved in the sale of Yuganskneftegas for $20 billion in damages. Yukos' US lawyers will attempt to have Baikal assets frozen after the Russian government ignored a US court order last week blocking the sale. Baikal's background and its motives for buying the unit are still unclear. Russian newspapers have claimed that Baikal, which bought the Yuganskneftegas production unit for $9.4 billion on Sunday at a state-arranged auction, has strong links with Surgutneftegas, Russia's fourth-biggest oil producer.

Hearts defeated Livingston 2-1 in their Scottish Cup quarter-final match with two goals in the opening 10 minutes. Lee Miller scored inside the opening 60 seconds, heading over Colin Meldrum and into the net from Jamie McAllister's free kick. McAllister himself scored the second when he met Saul Mikoliunas' cross at the back post to put the game beyond the visitors. Craig Easton headed in a controversial goal after an hour, but Hearts held on. The opening goal came after Gus Bahoken had clumsily fouled Miller 35 yards from goal. McAllister floated the free kick into the Livi box and Miller outjumped the static visiting defense to loop his header from 10 yards over Meldrum.

Jamieson, Scotland's justice minister, has warned bigoted soccer fans that she wants to "hit them where it hurts most" by banning them from matches. Cathy Jamieson said exclusion orders are one of a series of measures being considered in the Scottish Executive's campaign against sectarianism. She praised Celtic and Rangers for their work in tackling the problem. However, the minister said stopping sectarian abuse associated with old firm matches is a key objective.

Kevin Spacey, Kate Bosworth, and other Hollywood stars attended the British premiere of the new film, Beyond the Sea, at London's Leicester Square on Thursday. The film, inspired by the life of 1950s crooner Bobby Darin, stars Spacey, who wrote, directed, and sang all 18 songs on the film's soundtrack. Bosworth, 21, plays Darin's wife - real-life Hollywood actress Sandra Dee. "I knew absolutely nothing about Bobby Darin before this film, but now I'm a huge fan," Bosworth said, who attended the premiere with British boyfriend Orlando Bloom.

Home phones may face an uncertain future as the fixed line phone in your home could soon become an endangered species. According to research by Nokia, more and more people are using their mobile phone for every call they make or take. The study showed that over 45 million people in the UK, Germany, US, and South Korea now only use a mobile. It was found that people keep their fixed line phone because call charges are lower, but most of those questioned said the future was definitely mobile. The Nokia-sponsored research showed that mobiles and fixed phones were used for different purposes. Home phones were used for longer calls but conversations on mobiles tended to be shorter, between mobiles and to friends.

A cross-party group has unveiled a draft bill proposing a smaller second chamber in which 70% of members would be elected. The government has postponed plans to remove the remaining hereditary peers because they said they were unlikely to succeed after opposition in the lords.

Scott Allan is confident of winning a medal at next week's European Indoor Championships after a solid debut on the international circuit. The 22-year-old Scot finished fourth in the 60m hurdles at the Jose M Cagigal Memorial Meeting in Madrid. "It was definitely a learning curve and I certainly haven't ruled out challenging for a medal next week," said the East Kilbride athlete.

A US woman is suing Hewlett-Packard (HP) for allegedly programming its printer ink cartridges to expire on a specific date. The unidentified woman from Georgia claims that a chip inside the cartridge sends a signal to the printer that it needs to be replaced, even if it still has ink. The lawsuit seeks to represent anyone in the US who has purchased an HP inkjet printer since February 2001. HP, the world's largest printer company, has declined to comment on the lawsuit.

Roxy Music on the Isle of Wight will appear at the Isle of Wight Music Festival, alongside Morrissey, Supergrass, and Idlewild. The band has already been confirmed as headliners for the three-day event, which takes place from June 10-12. Original band members Bryan Ferry, Phil Manzerana, Andy McKay, and Paul Thompson will take to the stage on the Saturday night of the festival. The band is also working on new material, their first since the 1982 album Avalon. Roxy Music was formed in 1971 by Ferry, McKay, and Brian Eno, with Manzerana joining the following year. Their first hit was 1972's "Virginia Plain," with other hits including "Street Life," "Love Is the Drug," and the 1981 John Lennon cover, "Jealous Guy."

Spirit Awards hail the comedy "Sideways" as this year's independent Spirit Awards winner, taking home all six of the awards for which it was nominated. It was named Best Film, while Alexander Payne won Best Director and Best Screenplay, along with writing partner Jim Taylor. The film also won acting awards for stars Paul Giamatti, Thomas Haden Church, and Virginia Madsen. "Sideways" is tipped to do well at Sunday's Oscars, with five nominations.

Prince crowned 'top music earner' in 2004, beating Madonna and Elton John in US magazine Rolling Stone's annual list. The singer earned $56.5m (Â£30.4m) from concerts, album and publishing sales with his Musicology tour and album. He kept Madonna in second place, as she earned $54.9m (Â£29.5m) while embarking on her global re-invention tour. Simon and Garfunkel were in 10th place, their comeback tour helping them earn $24.9m (Â£13.4m) last year.

U2, the Irish rock band, has been honored at France's biggest music awards, but was beaten to a prize by the Irish band, Blue. U2 received a special achievement prize at the NRJ music awards, but Blue beat them to the international group award. Maroon 5 was named best new international artist, and took the best international song title for this love. More than five million radio listeners voted in the awards. The international male and female prizes went to Usher and Avril Lavigne respectively. Collecting his band's award from model Naomi Campbell at the Cannes ceremony, U2 frontman Bono said in French  "I'm not from this country, but I'll make a little confession to you - it's at the CÃ´te d'Azur I feel at home."

Tories outlining policing plans for local communities would be asked to go to the polls to elect their own area police commissioner, under plans unveiled by the conservatives. Party leader Michael Howard said the new role would replace "inconspicuous" police authorities. He stated the new office would not supersede the job of a chief constable. The Liberal Democrats said the plan could let extreme groups run policing, while Labour criticised "extravagant" Tory promises on policing. Responding to the plans, the chairman of the Police Federation of England and Wales, which represents rank and file officers, said it was essential operational independence was retained.

At a glance: Tory health checks: The UK's opposition has unveiled plans to introduce health checks for immigrants if they win the general election. A guide to the plan: people coming to live and work in Britain from outside the EU. If they plan to stay six months or more and are from a country with lots of TB, they would have to have a chest X-ray and further tests if appropriate. All people from outside the European Union who want to stay a year or more will have to undergo a full medical. Tuberculosis, hepatitis B, and HIV. A positive test for TB would automatically mean visa applications being turned down. All other conditions would be dealt with on a case-by-case basis.

Paris has hosted a better Six Nations match than Saturday's epic in Paris? And can the Welsh revival continue all the way to a first Grand Slam since 1978? Those are the two questions occupying not just Wales supporters but rugby fans as a whole after a scintillating display in Paris. Welsh legend Mervyn Davies, a member of two of three Grand Slam-winning sides of the 1970s, hailed it as "one of the great performances of the past three decades". Martyn Williams, Wales' two-try scorer on the day, called it "one of the most surreal games I have ever played in". A crestfallen France coach, Bernard Laporte, simply observed  "There was a French half and there was a Welsh half."

Doves soar to the top of the UK album chart, replacing Scissor Sisters at number one with their new release, "Some Cities". The trio's album follows the success of their single "Black and White Town", which peaked at number six. Nelly's new single "Over and Over" takes the top spot, featuring Tim McGraw. Other notable entries in the top ten include Girls Aloud, Akon, and Kaiser Chiefs, as well as Futureheads and Usher. Elvis Presley's re-released "Elvis Presley" album, "(Marie's the Name) His Latest Flame", debuts at number three, just behind Girls Aloud's "Wake Me Up". Akon's "Locked Up" sits at number five, while Kaiser Chiefs' "Oh My God" enters the chart at number six.

Davies is likely to remain with Gloucester despite reported interest from the Ospreys. According to BBC Wales, the Ospreys are interested in the 32-year-old hooker, but Davies prefers to stay where he is. As one of the stars of Saturday's RBS Six Nations win over England, Davies has proved his worth to the Zurich Premiership side and is likely to secure a new deal next season.

Cabinet anger at Brown's cash raid, ministers are unhappy about plans to use Whitehall cash to keep council tax bills down, local government Minister Nick Raynsford has acknowledged. Gordon Brown has reallocated Â£512m from central to local government budgets in his pre-budget report on Thursday. Mr Raynsford said he had held some "pretty frank discussions" with fellow ministers over the plans. He said local governments had to deliver good services without big council tax rises.

Israeli club Hapoel Bnei Sakhnin is set to make history by fielding four African players, including Zimbabwean goalkeeper Energy Murambadoro, in the UEFA Cup. This marks a significant milestone for the Arab side, who will face English Premier League team Newcastle United in the first round. Murambadoro, a standout performer at the African Nations Cup finals in Tunisia, played a crucial role in helping Bnei Sakhnin overcome Partizani Tirana of Albania 6-1 in the previous round. The 25-year-old goalkeeper recently joined the club after a brief stint with South African side Hellas. Bnei Sakhnin won the Israeli Cup final last season and is based in Sakhnin, near Haifa.

A new report suggests that reducing the drink-drive limit could save more lives than previously thought. According to a University College London study, cutting the limit from 80mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood to 50mg would save 65 lives a year. The research, conducted by transport expert Professor Richard Allsop, also indicates that this change would lead to 230 fewer serious injuries on the UK's roads, resulting in an estimated Â£119m annual savings.

This paper introduces a millimeter-scale CMOS 64x64 single charged particle radiation detector system for external beam cancer radiotherapy. A 1x1 Î¼mÂ² diode measures energy deposition by a single charged particle in the depletion region, and the array design provides a large detection area of 512x512 Î¼mÂ². Instead of sensing the voltage drop caused by radiation, the proposed system measures the pulse width, i.e., the time it takes for the voltage to return to its baseline, eliminating the need for power-hungry analog-to-digital converters.

Routing controllability of autonomous vehicles (AVs) has been shown to reduce the impact of selfish routing on network efficiency. However, the assumption that AVs would readily allow themselves to be controlled externally by a central agency is unrealistic. In this paper, we propose a joint routing and pricing control scheme that aims to incentivize AVs to seek centrally controlled system optimal (SO) routing by saving on tolls while user equilibrium (UE) seeking AVs and human-driven vehicles (HVs) are subject to a congestion charge. The problem is formulated as a bi-level optimization, in which dynamic tolls are optimized in the upper level, whereas the lower level is a mixed equilibrium simulation-based dynamic traffic assignment model considering a mixed fleet of AVs and HVs.

Optomechanics and electromechanics have enabled the preparation of macroscopic mechanical oscillators in their quantum ground states, in quadrature squeezed states, and in entangled states of motion. This capability has encouraged ideas for using mechanical oscillators in the processing and communication of quantum information and as precision force sensors operating beyond the standard quantum limit. The effectively linear interaction between motion and light or electricity precludes access to the broader class of quantum states of motion, such as cat states or energy squeezed states. However, optomechanical proposals have noted the possibility of escaping this restriction by creating strong quadratic coupling of motion to light.

Online reviews provide product evaluations for customers to make informed decisions. Unfortunately, these evaluations can be manipulated by professional spammers using fake reviews, who adapt to deployed detectors and employ increasingly sophisticated spamming strategies. These strategies are difficult to capture, as they can evolve quickly over time, vary across spammers and target products, and remain unknown in most cases. To address this challenge, we propose a game where spammers and detectors compete on their practical goals, not solely focused on detection accuracy. This approach leads to stable detectors that are agnostic to any mixed detection strategies.

We developed single-shot shaped pulses for ultra-high fidelity population transfer on a 3-level quantum system in a lambda configuration. To ensure high fidelity, we utilize the Lewis-Riesenfeld method to derive a family of solutions leading to an exact transfer, where the solutions follow a single dynamical mode of the Lewis-Riesenfeld invariant. Among this family, we identify a tracking solution with a single parameter to control simultaneously the fidelity of the transfer, the population of the excited state, and robustness. We define a measure of the robustness of an ultra-high-fidelity transfer as the minimum percentile deviation on the pulse areas at which the infidelity rises above 10^-4. The robustness of our shaped pulses is found superior to that of Gaussian and adiabatically-optimized pulses for moderate pulse areas.

In this paper, we examine the landscape of the population negative log-likelihood function of Gaussian mixture models with a general number of components. Due to non-convexity, multiple local minima exist, even when the mixture is well-separated. We show that all local minima share the same form of structure that partially identifies the component centers of the true mixture, in the sense that each local minimum involves a non-overlapping combination of fitting multiple Gaussians to a single true component and fitting a single Gaussian to multiple true components. Our results apply to the setting where the true mixture components satisfy a certain separation condition, and are valid even when the number of components is over- or under-specified. For Gaussian mixtures with three components, we obtain sharper results in terms of the scaling with the separation between the components.

We consider the connection between two constructions of the mirror partner for the Calabi-Yau orbifold. This orbifold is defined as a quotient by a suitable subgroup g of the phase symmetries of the hypersurface x_m in the weighted projective space, cut out by a quasi-homogeneous polynomial w_m. The first Berglund-Hubsch-Krawitz (BHK) construction uses another weighted projective space and the quotient of a new hypersurface x_mt inside it by a dual group gt. In the second, Batyrev construction, the mirror partner is constructed as a hypersurface in the toric variety defined by the reflexive polytope dual to the polytope associated with the original Calabi-Yau orbifold.

In this study, a generalization of the human gait was derived from existing models in the literature, including models of Keller and Kockschen. In this hybrid model, a metabolic energy minimization strategy is combined with a non-linear description of the movement of the mass center's libration, aiming to reproduce the behavior of the walk-run transition. Experimental data for various speed regimes indicate that the perimeter of the trajectory of the mass center is a significant quantity in the quantification of this dynamic process.

We present a novel mixed-variable symplectic integrator for planetary systems, resolving close encounters with a novel time regularization approach that maintains the stability properties of symplectic integrators while reducing the effective step size near close encounters. Our high-order scheme enables integration with large time steps, even at a distance from close encounters. We demonstrate that this algorithm resolves almost exact collisions (i.e., with a mutual separation of a fraction of the physical radius) using the same time-step as in weakly perturbed problems, such as the solar system. The long-term behavior of our algorithm is shown on systems of six super-Earths experiencing strong scattering over 50,000 years. We compare our method to hybrid approaches like Mercury and find that, at an equivalent cost, we achieve much better energy conservation.

Entanglement is a crucial resource for quantum information processing. A widely used tool for detecting entanglement is the entanglement witness, where the measurement of the witness operator is guaranteed to be positive for all separable states and can be negative for certain entangled states. Due to the exponentially increasing Hilbert-space dimension with respect to the system size, constructing an efficient entanglement witness for general multipartite entangled states is very challenging. For n-partite GHZ-like states, the most robust witness scheme requires n+1 local measurement settings and can tolerate up to 1/2 white noise.

Within general relativity, the unique stationary solution of an isolated black hole is the Kerr spacetime, which has a peculiar multipolar structure depending only on its mass and spin. We develop a general method to extract the multipole moments of arbitrary stationary spacetimes and apply it to a large family of horizonless microstate geometries. The latter can break the axial and equatorial symmetry of the Kerr metric and have a much richer multipolar structure, providing a portal to constrain fuzzball models phenomenologically. We find numerical evidence that all multipole moments are typically larger than those of a Kerr black hole with the same mass and spin.

Reasoning about graphs evolving over time is a challenging concept in many domains, including bioinformatics, physics, and social networks. We consider a common case in which edges can be short-term interactions, or long-term structural connections. In practice, long-term edges are often specified by humans. Human-specified edges can be both expensive to produce and suboptimal for the downstream task. To alleviate these issues, we propose a model based on temporal point processes and variational autoencoders that learns to infer temporal attention between nodes by observing node communication.

Observations of thermally driven transverse vibration of a photonic crystal waveguide (PCW) are reported. The PCW consists of two parallel nanobeams with a 240 nm vacuum gap between the beams. Models are developed and validated for transducing beam motion to phase and amplitude modulation of a weak optical probe propagating in a guided mode (GM) of the PCW for probe frequencies far from and near to the dielectric band edge. This research provides a foundation for evaluating possible deleterious effects of thermal motion on optical atomic traps near the surfaces of PCWs.

We establish natural splittings for the values of global Mackey functors at orthogonal, unitary, and symplectic groups. In particular, the restriction homomorphisms between the orthogonal, unitary, and symplectic groups of adjacent dimensions are naturally split epimorphisms. The interest in the splitting comes from equivariant stable homotopy theory. The equivariant stable homotopy groups of every global spectrum form a global Mackey functor, so the splittings imply that certain long exact homotopy group sequences separate into short exact sequences.

Baryonic feedback effects lead to a suppression of the weak lensing angular power spectrum on small scales. The poorly constrained shape and amplitude of this suppression are an important source of uncertainties for upcoming cosmological weak lensing surveys, such as Euclid or LSST. We use simulations to build a Euclid-like tomographic mock data-set for the cosmic shear power spectrum and the corresponding covariance matrix, both corrected for baryonic effects following the baryonification method of Schneider et al. (2019). We also develop an emulator to obtain fast predictions of the baryonic power suppression, allowing us to perform a likelihood inference analysis for a standard LCDM cosmology with both cosmological and astrophysical parameters.

In real-world settings, such as child-centered recordings, spontaneous conversations have been found to be particularly challenging for audio processing. However, building speech processing models that can handle such a wide range of conditions would be highly useful for language acquisition studies, where researchers are interested in the quality and quantity of speech that children hear and produce. Additionally, it would be valuable for early diagnosis and measuring the effects of remediation. In this paper, we present our approach to designing an open-source neural network to classify audio segments into vocalizations produced by the child, vocalizations produced by other children, adult male speech, and adult female speech.

Density-based clustering relies on the idea of linking groups to specific features of the probability distribution underlying the data, framing the clustering problem in a standard inferential setting. The concept of ideal population clustering is defined as the partition induced by the true density function. The nonparametric formulation of this approach, known as modal clustering, draws a correspondence between groups and domains of attraction of the density modes. A nonparametric density estimate is required, and a proper selection of the amount of smoothing, governing the shape of the density and hence possibly the modal structure, is crucial to identify the final partition.

The tails of diboson production at the LHC are sensitive to the interference between standard model and higher-dimensional operators, parameterizing the effects of heavy new physics. However, helicity selection rules for the diboson scattering amplitudes set an obstruction to the naive interference contributions of dimension-six operators, causing the total diboson rate correction's leading contribution to cancel. In this case, measuring the azimuthal decay angles "resurrects" the interference, recouping sensitivity to the non-interfering operators. We explore these signatures in detail, finding that the EFT uncertainties associated with higher-dimensional operators are uniquely well-suppressed by the construction of an asymmetry variable, which is only generated by these non-interfering operators, relegating the effects of higher-dimensional, interfering operators to the same status as statistical errors in this observable.

Causal inference from observational data is the goal of many data analyses in the health and social sciences. However, academic statistics has often frowned upon data analysis with a causal objective. The introduction of the term "data science" provides a historic opportunity to redefine data analysis in such a way that it naturally accommodates causal inference from observational data. Like others before, we organize the scientific contributions of data science into three classes of tasks  description, prediction, and counterfactual prediction.

The weak gravity conjecture demands the existence of superextremal particles in any consistent quantum theory of gravity. The standard lore suggests that these particles ensure the stability of extremal black holes, but it's unclear what goes wrong if this doesn't happen. This note highlights the tension between rigorously proven quantum information theorems about entanglement entropy and the exact stability of extremal black branes in a generic Einstein quantum theory of gravity in AdS. Avoiding this contradiction leads to a non-perturbative version of the WGC, which reduces to the usual statement at weak coupling. The argument is general, relying only on the validity of Einstein's gravity, effective field theory, and holography.

Understanding the strong correlation between two-dimensional (2D) systems can lead to unconventional superconductivity at high critical temperatures, a major unsolved problem in condensed matter physics. Ultracold 2D Fermi gases have emerged as clean and controllable model systems to study the interplay of strong correlations and reduced dimensionality. Here, we demonstrate superfluidity in an ultracold 2D Fermi gas by moving a periodic potential through the system and observing no dissipation below a critical velocity v_c. We measure v_c as a function of interaction strength and find a maximum in the crossover regime between bosonic and fermionic superfluidity.

Ordinary differential equations (ODEs) are mathematical models widely used in various fields, including climatology, bioinformatics, and chemical engineering, due to their intuitive ability to model complex phenomena. However, the frequent absence of their analytical solutions makes it challenging to estimate ODE parameters from data, especially when the model has many variables and parameters. This paper presents a Bayesian ODE parameter estimation algorithm that is fast and accurate, even for models with numerous parameters. The proposed method approximates an ODE model with a state-space model based on equations of a numeric solver, allowing for fast estimation by avoiding the computation of the entire numerical solution. The posterior is obtained through a variational Bayesian method, specifically, the approximate Riemannian conjugate gradient method.

We study the transport properties and superconducting proximity effect in NSN junctions formed by a time-reversal symmetry broken Weyl semimetal (WSM) in proximity to an S-wave superconductor. We find that the differential conductance and induced pairing amplitudes strongly depend on the angle between the junction direction in real space and the axis separating the Weyl nodes in momentum space. We identify the influence of a chiral chemical potential, i.e., the electron population imbalance between Weyl nodes of opposite chirality, on the transport characteristics of the junction. Notably, we observe a net spin polarization of Cooper pairs generated via Andreev reflection in the two WSM regions. The spin polarization is opposite in the two WSM regions and highly sensitive to the chirality imbalance and excitation energy.

Metal ion implantation into ceramics has been demonstrated as an effective and controllable technique for tailoring the surface electrical conductivity of the ceramic piece, and this approach has been used in a number of applications. This method provides a way to grade the voltage drop across high-voltage insulators, thereby increasing the maximum operational voltage that can be applied across the insulator without surface flashover. A concern for the use of this method is the long-term stability of the implantation-induced conductivity, especially if the implanted metal species is readily oxidized. We report on our examination of the long-term behavior of the surface conductivity of titanium-implanted alumina. The results indicate that after an initial drop of up to 40% in the first few weeks after implantation, the conductivity shows only a slow decrease of about 10% over the following year.

We introduce a novel Skyrme-like conserved current in the effective theory of pions and vector mesons, rooted in the concept of hidden local symmetry. The associated charge is equivalent to the skyrmion charge for any smooth configuration. Moreover, singular configurations can be identified as n_f=1 baryons charged under the new symmetry. Under this identification, vector mesons assume the role of Chern-Simons vector fields residing on the quantum Hall droplet that forms the n_f=1 baryon. We propose that this current accurately represents the baryon current at low energies. This proposal yields a unified framework for the two types of baryons, enabling a natural transformation between them. Additionally, Chern-Simons dualities on the droplet can be viewed as a result of Seiberg-like duality between gluons and vector mesons.

Interfacial spin-orbit coupling in Josephson junctions presents an intriguing opportunity to combine anomalous Hall and Josephson physics in a single device. We theoretically investigate how the superposition of both effects influences the transport properties of superconductor/ferromagnetic insulator/superconductor junctions. The superposition generates sizable transverse Hall supercurrents, which we refer to as anomalous Josephson Hall effect currents. We extend the Furusaki-Tsukada formula to quantify the transverse current components and demonstrate that their amplitudes are adjustable by the spin-orbit coupling strengths or the superconducting phase difference. As a distinct spectroscopic signature of Josephson junctions, well-localized subgap bound states form around the interface.

Following the suggestion from the Monte Carlo experiments in Jimenez et al. (2020), that dipoles are as important to the dynamics of decaying two-dimensional turbulence as individual vortex cores, it is found that the kinetic energy of this flow is carried by elongated streams formed by the concatenation of dipoles. Vortices separate into a family of small, fast-moving cores and another family of larger, slowly moving ones, which can be described as "frozen" into a slowly evolving "crystal".

Continuous-time quantum walks have proven to be an extremely useful framework for designing several quantum algorithms. The running time of quantum algorithms in this framework is characterized by the quantum hitting time, which is the time required by the quantum walk to find a vertex of interest with a high probability. We provide improved upper bounds for the quantum hitting time that can be applied to several ctqw-based quantum algorithms. In particular, we apply our techniques to the glued-trees problem, improving their hitting time upper bound by a polynomial factor, from O(n^5) to O(n^2logn). Our methods also help to exponentially improve the dependence on precision of the continuous-time quantum walk-based algorithm to find a marked node on any ergodic, reversible Markov chain.

Extreme mass ratio inspirals (EMRIs) can be classified as dry EMRIs and wet EMRIs based on their formation mechanisms. Dry (or the "loss-cone") EMRIs, previously considered as the main EMRI sources for the laser interferometer space antenna, are primarily produced by multi-body scattering in the nuclear star cluster and gravitational capture. We highlight an alternative EMRI formation channel  wet EMRI formation assisted by the accretion flow around accreting galactic-center massive black holes (MBHs). In this channel, the accretion disk captures stellar-mass black holes that are initially moving on inclined orbits, and subsequently drives them to migrate towards the MBH, boosting the formation rate of EMRIs in such galaxies by orders of magnitude.

When a new user signs up on a website, we usually have no information about him/her, i.e. no interaction with items, no user profile, and no social links with other users. Under such circumstances, we still expect our recommender systems to attract the users at the first time, so that the users decide to stay on the website and become active users. This problem falls into the new user cold-start category and is crucial to the development and survival of a company.

Deep learning has solved many problems that are out of reach of heuristic algorithms, even in wireless communications, where optimal algorithms exist. It has also been successfully applied, despite well-understood current systems. Some gains have been obtained by learning individual parts of a receiver, but a better approach is to jointly learn the whole receiver. However, this often results in a challenging nonlinear problem, for which the optimal solution is infeasible to implement. To address this, we propose a deep, fully convolutional neural network, deeprx, which executes the whole receiver pipeline from frequency domain signal stream to uncoded bits in a 5G-compliant manner.

Mutation-based fuzzing typically uses an initial set of non-crashing seed inputs from which to generate new inputs by mutation. To address this, fuzzers come with distillation tools that select the smallest subset of seeds that triggers the same range of instrumentation data points as the full corpus. This leads to more efficient fuzzing, which we explore systematically.

In this paper, we investigate multi-agent discrete-event systems with partial observation. The agents can be divided into several groups, in each of which the agents have similar isomorphic state transition structures, and thus can be relabeled into the same template. Based on the template, a scalable supervisor whose state size and computational cost are independent of the number of agents is designed for the case of partial observation. The scalable supervisor under partial observation does not need to be recomputed regardless of how many agents are added to or removed from the system. We generalize our earlier results to partial observation by proposing sufficient conditions for safety and maximal permissiveness of the scalable least restrictive supervisor on the template level.

Electric network frequency fluctuations constitute a powerful tool in multimedia forensics. An efficient approach for estimation is introduced with temporal windowing based on the filter-bank spectral estimator. A type of Gohberg-Semencul factorization of the model covariance matrix is used due to the Toeplitz structure of the covariance matrix. Moreover, this approach uses, for the first time in the field of enf, a temporal window, not necessarily the rectangular one, at the stage preceding spectral estimation. Krylov matrices are employed for fast implementation of matrix inversions. The proposed approach outperforms the state-of-the-art methods in enf estimation, when a short time window of 1 second is employed in power recordings.

The direpack package aims to introduce a set of modern statistical dimension reduction techniques to the python universe as a single, consistent package. It includes dimension reduction methods categorized into three: projection pursuit, sufficient dimension reduction, and robust M-estimators for dimension reduction. Regularized regression estimators based on these reduced dimension spaces are also provided, ranging from classical principal component regression to sparse partial robust M regression. The package also contains a set of classical and robust pre-processing utilities, including generalized spatial signs, as well as dedicated plotting functionality and cross-validation utilities. Consistent with the scikit-learn API, direpack estimators can be seamlessly integrated into statistical and machine learning pipelines.

The nonlinear fluorescence emission has been widely applied for high spatial resolution optical imaging. Here, we studied the fluorescence anomalous saturating effect of the nitrogen vacancy defect in diamond. The fluorescence reduction was observed with high power laser excitation. It increased the nonlinearity of the fluorescence emission, and changed the spatial frequency distribution of the fluorescence image. We used a differential excitation protocol to extract high spatial frequency information. By modulating the excitation laser's power, the spatial resolution of imaging was improved approximately 1.6 times compared to confocal microscopy. Due to the simplicity of the experimental setup and data processing, this method is expected to be used for improving the spatial resolution of sensing and biological labeling with defects in solids.

When random effects are correlated with sample design variables, the standard approach of employing individual survey weights (constructed to be inversely proportional to the unit survey inclusion probabilities) no longer produces asymptotically unbiased inference. We construct a weight-exponentiated formulation for the random effects distribution that achieves unbiased inference for generating hyperparameters of the random effects. Our approach contrasts with frequentist methods that rely on numerical integration, revealing that only the Bayesian method achieves both unbiased estimation with respect to the sampling design distribution and consistency with respect to the population generating distribution. Our simulations and real data example demonstrate the utility of our approach across different modeling formulations and sampling designs.

Low-symmetry 2D materials, such as res2 and rese2 monolayers, black phosphorus monolayers, group-IV monochalcogenide monolayers, borophene, and others, exhibit more intricate atomistic structures compared to the honeycomb lattices of graphene, hexagonal boron nitride, and transition metal dichalcogenides. The reduced symmetries of these emerging materials give rise to inhomogeneous electron, optical, valley, and spin responses, as well as novel properties, including ferroelasticity, ferroelectricity, magnetism, spin-wave phenomena, large nonlinear optical properties, photogalvanic effects, and superconductivity.

Orientational dynamics in the isotropic phase of a comb-shaped nematic polymer with mesogenic and functional side groups was studied using the Kerr effect and dielectric spectroscopy. It was found that in a mesogenic polymer, unlike low-molecular-weight mesogens, the relaxation of the electric birefringence of a melt above the temperature of the nematic-isotropic phase transition can be presented by a sum of several exponential processes, with two playing a decisive role. These main processes replace each other in a temperature range of about fifty degrees. Dielectric spectroscopy also enabled the distinction of two processes of orientational relaxation  the first is due to the rotation of side mesogenic groups, and the second is associated with the motion of main chain segments.

Deep hashing methods have shown great retrieval accuracy and efficiency in large-scale image retrieval. Optimizing discrete hash bits is always the focus in deep hashing methods. A common strategy in these methods is to adopt an activation function, e.g., sigmoid or tanh, and minimize a quantization loss to approximate discrete values.
